section.heading: Board Established.
section.text: There is an Inclusionary Housing Board.

para.text: In general.
The Board is comprised of the following 10 members:
4 members appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the City Council in accordance with City Charter article IV, § 6; and
3 members nominated by the Council President, appointed by the Mayor, and confirmed by the City Council in accordance with City Charter Article IV, § 6;
the Housing Commissioner or the Housing Commissioner's designee;
the Planning Director or the Planning Director's designee; and
the Director of the Office of Equity and Civil Rights or the Director's designee, who shall serve as a non-voting member of the Board.
Of the 4 members appointed by the Mayor:
1 must be a for-profit developer with experience in public financing;
1 must be a lender or investor with experience in multi-family projects and public financing or a mixed income or multi-family developer;
1 must have experience in housing, community development, planning, social services, or public health; and
1 must be a renter earning an income at or below 60% AMI.
Of the 3 members nominated by the Council President:
1 must be a for-profit multi-family developer that uses public financing, subsidies, or tax credits;
1 must be a nonprofit affordable housing developer; and
1 must be a renter earning an income at or below 60% AMI.
Qualifications – Residency.
All of the members must be residents of the City.
The Mayor designates 1 of the appointed members to be the Chair of the Board.
The Board may appoint a Vice-Chair and other officers as necessary or appropriate.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Board:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

para.heading: Meetings.
para.text: The Board meets on the call of the Chair as frequently as required to perform its duties.

para.heading: Quorum.
para.text: A majority of the members constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business.

para.heading: Voting.
para.text: An affirmative vote of at least a majority of a quorum is needed for any official action.

section.heading: Staff.
section.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development must provide staff for the Board.

para.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Commissioner must:

submit a report to the Mayor and the City Council, the Board,and to the Planning Commission that assesses efforts during the preceding fiscal year to create and sustain inclusionary housing in the City;
post the report on the Department of Housing and Community Development's website; and
file the report with the Department of Legislative Reference.
Contents generally.
The report must include:
the total number of new affordable units created under this subtitle for that year and cumulatively for moderate, low, very low, and extremely low income households;
for that year, the percent of new dwelling units created in the City that are affordable units for moderate, low, very low, and extremely low income households;
aggregated annual data provided under § 2B-24{"Annual report - Residential project."} of this subtitle; and
attach the annual reports from the properties with new affordable units created under this subtitle.

section.heading: Duties.
section.text: In addition to the other duties specified elsewhere in this subtitle, the Board is responsible for:

para.text: reviewing and providing comments on the regulations promulgated under § 2B-3 {"Rules and Regulations"} of this subtitle; and
reviewing and providing comments on inclusionary housing plans submitted by residential projects to the Board as required under § 2B-22 {"Inclusionary housing plan"} of this subtitle.
This section applies to any residential project :
that provides 20 or more dwelling units;
that receives:
a major public subsidy; or
a significant land use authorization;
that is newly constructed, wholly renovated, or converted from a non-residential building; and
the cost of the construction or conversion exceeds $60,000 per rental unit.
In every residential project subject to this section, at least 5% of all dwelling units for rent must be affordable units to low income households.
In every residential project subject to this section, at least 5% of all dwelling units for rent must be affordable units to very low income households.

In every residential project where the developer is offered an additional subsidy or offered the opportunity to apply for an additional subsidy for affordable units for very low income or extremely low income households, up to an additional 5% of dwelling units for rent must be affordable to very low and extremely low income households upon an award of the additional subsidy.

If the City negotiates or a residential project promises to provide a greater percentage of affordability or longer time period of affordability, that more restrictive provision governs over the requirements of this subtitle to the extent of any conflict.
Exclusions.
The provisions of this section do not apply to:
dormitories, as defined in § 1-305(g) of the Zoning Code;
fraternity or sorority houses, as defined in § 1-306(p) of the Zoning Code;
residential-care facilities, as defined in § 1-312(p) of the Zoning Code; or
a residential project that is designed for, marketed to, and leased to students enrolled in accredited educational institutions located in Baltimore City, also known as "student housing".

Residential projects subject to the affordability unit requirements of this subtitle must submit an inclusionary housing plan to the Department of Housing and Community Development and the Inclusionary Housing Board when applying for a building permit.
In general.
Residential projects required to submit an inclusionary housing plan under subsection (a) must submit a plan in the form established by the Commissioner.

An inclusionary housing plan must include a plan for affirmatively marketing the affordable units in the residential project to those individuals least likely to apply to become tenants without special outreach efforts.

text.em: Review and comment on inclusionary housing plan.

para.text: Before the City issues building permits for a residential project that is subject to the affordability unit requirements of this subtitle, the residential project's inclusionary housing plan must first be reviewed and commented upon by the Inclusionary Housing Board.

text.em: Commissioner authority to create inclusionary housing plan form.

para.text: The Commissioner, with the advice and consent of the Inclusionary Housing Board, shall create and amend as necessary a form for an inclusionary housing plan.

section.heading: Fair housing laws and regulations.
section.text: All residential projects created under this subtitle are subject to applicable federal, state, and local housing laws and regulations.

para.text: Residential projects subject to the affordability requirements of this subtitle must submit an annual report to the Department and the Inclusionary Housing Board.
The contents of the annual report required under subsection (a) of this section must include:
the number of affordable units in the residential project for each income level applicable under this subtitle;
the square footage of each bedroom in each affordable unit;
whether an affordable unit is leased and occupied at the time of the report and to which income level the tenant belongs;
whether or not the residential project is in compliance with the inclusionary housing plan;

the number of tenants, delineated by group, occupying affordable units who were identified as belonging to a group least likely to lease as a result of the affirmative marketing required under § 2B-22(b) {"Inclusionary housing plan requirements"} of this subtitle;
an accounting of the monthly rent collected for each affordable unit for that year, as prepared by an independent accountant;

a comparison, displayed as both a number and percentage, of the monthly rent collected for each affordable unit against the monthly rent that could have been collected if each affordable unit was a market-rate unit, as prepared by an independent accountant;
an accounting of the efficacy of the high-performance inclusionary tax credit;
the type of major public subsidy that made the residential project subject to the affordability unit requirements of this subtitle; and
any additional information related to compliance with this subtitle or any rules and regulations issued under this subtitle as determined by the Commissioner.
The Commissioner will prominently post all annual reports required under subsection (a) of this section on the City's website.

section.heading: Comparable design.
section.text: The affordable units required by this subtitle:

para.text: must be complementary to the market rate units in the same project as to their exterior appearance;
must be comparable to the market rate units in the same project as to:
number of bedrooms; and
overall quality of construction; and
may vary in size and finish, consistent with standards set forth in the Commissioner's rules and regulations.
The affordable units required by this subtitle must be dispersed throughout the residential project.
The affordable units required by this subtitle must be constructed and completed in the same time frame as the market rate units of the project.
The mix of affordable units required by this subtitle must be at the same ratio as the offerings for the building as a whole.
If a building offers different price points for units with identical numbers of bedrooms and bathrooms, the inclusionary unit must be for the floor plan with the lowest monthly rent.
No penthouse units will be included in the count of affordable units.

section.heading: Right of first refusal.
section.text: Repealed.

section.heading: Eligibility to purchase or rent.
section.text: Repealed.

section.heading: Management of rental units.
section.text: An affordable rental unit provided under this subtitle must be managed under the same management standards as all market-rate rental units in the development.

para.text: The City or designated housing providers may enter master lease agreements to manage affordable units developed to comply with § 2B-21(b)(2) {"Inclusionary requirements."} of this article.
The Commissioner may designate housing providers to manage and rent affordable units in accordance with the regulations and procedures adopted by the Commissioner.

Every affordable rental unit subject to this subtitle must remain at an affordable housing cost, as provided in this section, for a period of not less than 30 years from the date of its initial occupancy.

1 year prior to the expiration of the affordability period, the owner shall notify the Department of Housing and Community Development of the opportunity to master lease the affordable units, at which time, the City or designated nonprofit housing providers may have the first right of refusal to master lease the affordable units to continue affordability after the affordability period expires.

During the affordability period, the owner of the rental property may not rent or lease any affordable unit and a tenant may not sub-rent or sublease the unit except to an eligible household at a rent that does not exceed an affordable rent applicable to that unit.
All affordable units under this section must be initially leased to moderate, low, very low, or extremely low income households, as outlined in § 2B-21 of this subtitle {"Inclusionary requirements"}.
If a tenant's income increases:
the tenant will be allowed to stay in the unit; and
the tenant's rent can be increased at the same ratio as the original leasing.
If the income of a tenant in an affordable unit, as described in this section, increases to 100% of AMI:
the tenant shall pay full market rent; and
another unit must be made available to comply with the affordability requirements in this section.
The owner of an affordable rental unit:
at all times must comply with all building, fire, safety, and other codes applicable to rental units; and
in providing maintenance and other services to rental units in the residential project, may not discriminate in any way against affordable units.

container.heading: Administrative Review, Judicial Review, and Penalties.

para.text: Any person aggrieved by a decision or ruling of the Commissioner under this subtitle may appeal that decision or ruling to the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals.
The appeal must be taken in writing within 15 days from the date of notice of the decision or ruling.
The Board:
must hold a hearing on the appeal as soon as practicable; and
may affirm, modify, or reverse the action from which the appeal was taken.

A party aggrieved by a final decision of the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals under § 2B- 51 {"Administrative appeals"} of this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.
Appellate review.
A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

The Department of Housing and Community Development shall issue a fine of no more than $1,000 to a person who violates a provision of this subtitle or a rule, regulation, or order adopted or issued under this subtitle.
Each violation a person commits of a provision of this subtitle or a rule, regulation, or order adopted or issued under this subtitle is a separate offense.
Each day a separate offense.
Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: Declaration of policy and findings of fact.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City Council finds that:
there live within the City of Baltimore persons and families who subsist in conditions of abject poverty;
there are concentrations of such persons and families in certain deteriorated neighborhoods within the City;
illiteracy, illegitimacy, crime, juvenile delinquency, ill health, and other symptoms of social breakdown all result from or are coincidental with such poverty and are rampant in said neighborhoods;
many of said impoverished persons and families are dependent upon public subsidy for their subsistence; and

many of the services available to help them attain a state of economic self-sufficiency and social productivity either are not being utilized by them or are being inappropriately utilized in uncoordinated, piecemeal fashion.

para.heading: Program of concerted action needed.
para.text: The City Council further finds that:

to eliminate the causes of poverty and the problems attendant upon it, it is imperative for the City of Baltimore to engage in a total program of concerted community action which will harness and synchronize its resources for remedial education, job training, health care, environmental improvement, social and physical rehabilitation, and training in home management and healthy family living; and
such a program, to be effective, must attack the problem at its source, in the neighborhoods.

para.heading: Division — established.
para.text: There is hereby created the Human Services Division in the Department of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Division — powers.
para.text: The Division shall have such powers and responsibilities as are granted to community action agencies under state law, and such other powers as are granted to it by law, ordinance, or resolution.

para.heading: Commission — established; powers.
para.text: There is hereby created the Human Services Commission, with membership as provided in this subtitle and with powers and responsibilities as may be determined by the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Commission — composition.
para.text: The Commission shall be composed of 31 members:
⅓ of the members shall be elected public officials selected by the Mayor to serve ex officio, or their representatives;
at least ⅓ of the members shall be persons chosen by a democratic selection method as determined by the Mayor to assure that they are representative of the poor in the area served;

the other members shall be officials or members of business, industry, labor, religious, welfare, education, or other major groups and interests in the community appointed by the Mayor pursuant to Article IV, § 6, of the Baltimore City Charter (1964 Revision, as amended).
If a vacancy occurs on the Commission, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled.
The Commission members shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for all expenses necessarily incurred.
Each member of the Commission shall serve for a term of 4 years, concurrent with the Mayor's term of office, and until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified.
No member may serve more than 1 full term, more than 5 consecutive years, or more than a total of 10 years.
Each member of the Commission shall be entitled to 1 vote.
A majority of said Commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business or the exercise of any power in the performance of any duty authorized or imposed by this subtitle.
The Mayor shall designate one appointed member of the Commission as its Chair, and the Commission shall elect a member as its Vice-Chair.
The Mayor shall appoint an Executive Deputy Commissioner, who shall be the head of the Division.
The Executive Deputy Commissioner shall serve for a period of 4 years and shall be appointed in the manner designated in Article IV, § 6 of the Baltimore City Charter (1964 Revision, as amended).
The Executive Deputy Commissioner shall have such duties as the Mayor shall impose upon the Executive Deputy Commissioner to execute the powers granted under this subtitle.

Until such time as an Executive Deputy Commissioner is appointed as provided herein, the Mayor shall appoint an Interim Executive Deputy Commissioner who shall perform the duties of the office until the aforesaid appointment is made.
The Executive Deputy Commissioner, when employing such other persons as may be required, shall comply with the provisions of the Baltimore City Charter relating to Civil Service.

Compensation of all persons so employed by the Division and all other necessary expenses shall be paid at such rates and in such amounts as the Board of Estimates shall approve and in accordance with the annual Ordinance of Estimates of the City of Baltimore.

container.heading: Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, Rooming Houses, and Vacant Structures

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 18-130, which substantially amended Subtitle 5 {“Licensing of Rental Dwellings”} of this article, also amended §§ 4-1, 4-6, 4-8, and 4-9 of this subtitle, all with a general effective date of August 1, 2018. Subsequently, Ordinance 20-428 (i) added a new § 4-12 to require the public posting of certain vacant structures with information of the structure’s ownership; (ii) repealed a provision (§ 4-7) that required certain vacant structure registration information to be confidential; and (iii) added a new § 4-14 to require the Housing Commissioner to submit an annual report detailing compliance with this subtitle – all with an effective date of May 1, 2021.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Commissioner.
para.text: "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Dwelling unit.
para.text: "Dwelling unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code.

para.heading: Multiple-family dwelling.
para.text: "Multiple-family dwelling" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Non-owner-occupied dwelling unit" means any:
dwelling unit that is unoccupied;
dwelling unit that, even if occupied, is not occupied by an owner of record; or

dwelling unit that, even if occupied, is not designated by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation as the owner's principal residence in accordance with the criteria governing the State Homestead Tax Credit.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: For purposes of this definition:
an owner may only have one owner-occupied dwelling unit in Baltimore City; and
an owner-occupied unit must be titled to a natural person.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except as used in § 4-17 {"Penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Rooming house.
para.text: "Rooming house" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code.

para.heading: Rooming unit.
para.text: "Rooming unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Vacant structure" means any structure that is subject to an unabated violation notice issued under § 116 {"Unsafe Structures"} of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Vacant structure" does not include an accessory structure that is not intended for occupancy, such as a garage, shed, or storage building.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This subtitle applies to:

para.text: every non-owner-occupied dwelling unit, whether or not it is occupied, fit for human habitation, or revenue producing;
every vacant structure, whether it is a residential structure, a non-residential structure, or other; and
every rooming house.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.text: The owner of any non-owner-occupied dwelling unit or of any rooming house must file an annual registration statement for that unit or rooming house with the Commissioner.
The owner of any vacant structure must file an annual registration statement for that structure with the Commissioner.
A new owner of a non-owner-occupied dwelling unit or of a rooming house must file the registration statement within 10 days of acquiring title to the unit or rooming house.

If the previous owner had registered the unit or rooming house and paid the applicable registration fee for the current registration period, the new owner need not pay any registration fee for that registration period.

para.heading: Newly vacant structure.
para.text: The owner of a vacant structure, whether or not previously registered as a non-owner-occupied dwelling unit or as a rooming house, must file a new registration statement and pay the fee applicable to vacant structures, within 10 days of the property's becoming a vacant structure.

para.heading: Form and contents.
para.text: Each registration statement must be in the form that the Commissioner requires and contain the following information:
a description of the premises by street number or by block-and-lot;
the name, street address, telephone number, and email address of the premises' owner of record;
the name, street address, telephone number, and email address of the premises' managing operator, if other than the owner; and

if the owner is a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability company, or similar entity, the name, street address, telephone number, and email address of a natural person who serves as the owner's chief executive officer, managing partner, or managing member, or in a similarly authoritative position.

para.heading: Change of listed information.
para.text: The Commissioner must be notified within 10 days of any change in the identity of or contact information for the owner of record or any other person listed in the registration statement.

para.heading: Base fee.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this section, an annual registration fee must be paid for rooming houses at the rate of $25 per rooming unit.

para.heading: Increased fee.
para.text: For any rooming house that has had the term of its rental dwelling license reduced under § 5-9(c) or (d) {"Rental dwellings: Tiered license terms"} of this article to a 1-year term, the annual registration fee under paragraph (1) of this subsection for each succeeding registration year beginning after the start of each 1-year rental dwelling license term is increased by an additional $15 per rooming unit, which additional amount shall be deposited in the continuing, nonlapsing fund created by City Charter Article I, § 14 {"Affordable Housing Trust Fund"}.

para.heading: Base fee.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this section, an annual registration fee must be paid for non-owner-occupied dwelling units at the following rates:

td.p: (1) for properties with 1 and 2 dwelling units –

$35 per dwelling unit,
plus $25 per rooming unit.

para.heading: Increased fee.
para.text: For any dwelling that has had the term of its rental dwelling license reduced under § 5-9(c) or (d) {"Rental dwellings: Tiered license terms"} of this article to a 1-year term, the annual registration fee under paragraph (1) of this subsection for each succeeding registration year beginning after the start of each 1-year rental dwelling license term is increased by an additional $15 per dwelling or rooming unit, which additional amount shall be deposited in the continuing, nonlapsing fund created by City Charter Article I, § 14 {"Affordable Housing Trust Fund"}.

para.heading: Vacant structures.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in this section, an annual registration fee, in addition to any fee that might also be required by subsection (a) or (b) of this section, must be paid for vacant structures at the following rates:

para.heading: When payable.
para.text: These fees must all be paid at the time of registration.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: No fee is charged for:
any dwelling unit, rooming house, or vacant structure that is owned by a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity; or
any dwelling unit that is not in a vacant structure and is owned by a nonprofit religious, charitable, or educational institution or organization.

section.heading: Term and renewal.
section.text: A registration expires on December 31 of each year, unless it is renewed and the annual registration fee paid before then.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If a person fails to pay the registration fee imposed by this subtitle within 30 days of the date on which it is due, the person is liable for the following, in addition to the registration fee:
interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the registration fee is overdue; and
a late fee at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the registration fee is overdue.

para.heading: Unpaid sum a personal debt and lien.

para.text: All registration fees, interest, and late fees provided for in this section are a personal debt owed by the owner of the property.
These fees and interest:
are a lien on the property in favor of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore; and
may be collected or enforced the same as any other debts or liens due to or in favor of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development shall affix, in a position that is conspicuous and visible from the street or road fronting the property, a sign containing:
the information set forth in § 4-6(a) {"Registration statement: Form and contents"} of this subtitle; or
at a minimum, information on how to access the information set forth in § 4-6(a) {"Registration statement: Form and contents"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Time.
para.text: The sign required by subsection (a) of this section must be posted within 10 days of registering the vacant structure with the Commissioner under § 4-5 {"Registration required"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Vacant structures in default or foreclosure.
para.text: In addition to the requirements set forth in subsection (a) of this section, if the property is in default or in foreclosure, the sign required by this section must also include the name, address, and telephone number of any creditors or lien holders.

para.heading: Sign specifications.
para.text: A sign required by this section must be:
impervious to weather conditions;
legibly written in a font size of not less than 18 points; and
no smaller than 8 ½ inches by 11 inches in size.

section.heading: Annual report.
section.text: On or before June 30 of each year, the Commissioner shall submit an annual report to the Mayor and City Council detailing compliance with this subtitle, including:

para.text: the number of properties registered under § 4-5 {"Registration required"} of this subtitle; and

the number of signs that the Department of Housing and Community Development has posted on vacant structures as required by § 4-12 {"Vacant structures: Posting ownership information"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates a provision of this subtitle or of a rule, regulation, or order adopted or issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

annotation.text: Ordinance 18-130 added the following uncodified, short-term transitional provisions for (i) preexisting, currently licensed multiple-family dwellings and rooming houses (Ord. 18-130, at Section 3) and (ii) non-owner-occupied dwelling units in 1- or 2-family dwellings (Ord. 18-130, at Section 4)

para.text: On and after the effective date of this Ordinance {August 1, 2018}, a preexisting multiple-family dwelling or rooming house operating under an unexpired license that was issued under former City Code Article 13, Subtitle 5, may continue to operate under that license:
until the license expires at the end of its stated term or
if the end of its stated term is fewer than 90 days after the effective date of this Ordinance, for an extended term that expires on the 90th day after the effective date of this Ordinance.

The multiple-family dwelling or rooming house may not continue to operate after the preexisting license expires under subsection (a)(i) or (ii) of this Section until the licensee has applied for and obtained an new, initial rental dwelling license under City Code Article 13, Subtitle 5, as amended by this Ordinance.

include.text: [O]n and after the effective date of this Ordinance {August 1, 2018}, a rental dwelling described in Article 13, § 5-1(g)(3), as added by this Ordinance, may preliminarily operate without an initial rental dwelling license, but only as long as:

para.text: all non-owner-occupied dwelling units are duly registered under Article 13, Subtitle 4, as amended by this Ordinance, and all registration fees and related interest and late fees required by that Subtitle 4 have been paid;

within 120 days of the effective date of this Ordinance, the owner submits a completed application under Article 13, Subtitle 5, as amended by this subtitle, for a new, initial rental dwelling license; and
the Housing Commissioner has not yet issued an approval or denial of that application.

annotations.annotation: The following text incorporates the many amendments made to this subtitle by Ordinance 18-130, subject to a general effective of August 1, 2018.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Dwelling unit.
para.text: "Dwelling unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Property Maintenance Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Housing Commissioner; Commissioner.
para.text: "Housing Commissioner" or "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Multiple-family dwelling.
para.text: "Multiple-family dwelling" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Property Maintenance Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Non-owner-occupied dwelling unit.
para.text: "Non-owner-occupied dwelling unit" has the meaning stated in § 4-1 of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Qualified inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes, except as used in § 5-21 {"Penalties"} of this subtitle, a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Priority dwelling" means a rental dwelling:
with 20 or more dwelling units or rooming units; and
to which 2 or more of the following criteria applied in the preceding calendar year:
the rental dwelling was issued a violation notice under the Building, Fire, and Related Codes article relating to interior conditions that remained unabated for more than 90 days;
the rental dwelling was issued four or more violation notices under the Building, Fire, and Related Codes article relating to interior conditions; and

the number of recorded 311 calls related to health and habitability for a rental dwelling , which may not include requests to summon law enforcement or emergency services as prohibited under § 14-126 of the State Real Property Article, divided by the total number of dwelling and rooming units in that rental dwelling, exceeds the applicable minimum value in the table below; and

the rental dwelling's U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) National Standards for the Physical Inspection of Real Estate (NSPIRE) inspection score for either of the 2 most recent NSPIRE inspections was less than or equal to 79.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This definition does not include any rental dwellings owned and operated by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Priority inspection.
para.text: "Priority inspection" means:
the physical inspection of a priority dwelling conducted by an inspector employed by the Department of Housing and Community Development; and

the inspector's written evaluation of the rental dwelling's compliance with the City's health and safety standards specified in the rules and regulations adopted by the Commissioner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Rental dwelling.
para.text: "Rental dwelling" means:
any multiple-family dwelling;
any rooming house;
any supportive housing facility; and
any non-owner-occupied dwelling unit in a 1- or 2-family dwelling that is leased or rented or offered or available for lease or rental in exchange for any form of consideration.

para.heading: Rooming house.
para.text: "Rooming house" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Property Maintenance Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Rooming unit.
para.text: "Rooming unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Property Maintenance Code of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Supportive housing facility.
para.text: "Supportive housing facility" has the meaning stated in § 202.2.56 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person may:
rent or offer to rent to another all or any part of any rental dwelling without a currently effective license to do so from the Housing Commissioner; or

charge, accept, retain, or seek to collect any rental payment or other compensation for providing to another the occupancy of all or any part of any rental dwelling unless the person was licensed under this subtitle at both the time of offering to provide and the time of providing this occupancy.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: A license is not required under this subtitle for any rental dwelling that is owned and operated by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City.

When the Department of Housing and Community Development has notice or actual knowledge that a rental dwelling is rented without a license as required in this section, the Commissioner shall promptly notify the record owner or the managing operator, if other than the record owner, to post a notice in the rental dwelling in an area accessible to all occupants.
The notice required in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall include:
a description of the duties and obligations of the record owner and managing operator of the rental dwelling regarding compliance with this subtitle;
the civil citations and criminal penalties that may arise under §§ 5-25 and 5-26 of this subtitle;
a statement that each day the violation continues is a separate offense; and
any additional information the Commissioner deems necessary to include.
The notice must remain posted for at least 90 days or until the building is licensed, whichever is longer.

para.heading: Notice to HABC.
para.text: When the Department of Housing and Community Development has notice or actual knowledge that a rental dwelling is rented without a license as required in this section, the Commissioner shall promptly notify the Housing Authority of Baltimore City, including any information the Commissioner deems necessary.

section.heading: Application for new or renewal license.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The application for a new or renewal rental dwelling license must be made in the form and contain the information and documentation that the Housing Commissioner requires.

para.heading: By whom to be made.
para.text: The application must be made and signed by:
the record owner of the premises; and
the managing operator of the premises, if other than the record owner.

para.heading: Application period for renewal.
para.text: To renew a license issued under this subtitle, an application for renewal must be submitted to the Commissioner no more than 120 days before the license expires.

para.heading: License application - Form and contents.
para.text: Each application for a new or renewed license, must contain the following information:
a description of the premises by street number and by block-and-lot numbers;
the name, street address, telephone number, and email address of the rental dwelling's record owner;
the name, street address, telephone number, and email address of the rental dwelling's managing operator, if other than the record owner; and
any other information requested by the Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

section.heading: Prerequisites for new or renewal license – In general.
section.text: A rental dwelling license may be issued or renewed under this subtitle only if:

para.text: all dwelling units and rooming units are currently registered as required by Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, Rooming Houses, and Vacant Structures"} of this article;
all registration fees for these units and all related interest and late fees required by Subtitle 4 have been paid;
the premises have passed an inspection, as required by § 5-7 {"Prerequisites ... – Inspection"} or § 5-10 {"Priority inspections"} of this subtitle;
the premises are in compliance with all Federal, State, and City laws and regulations governing lead paint;

for premises that include a hotel or motel subject to City Code Article 15 {"Licensing and Regulation"}, Subtitle 10 {"Hotels"}, the hotel or motel is in compliance with the training, certification, and posting requirements of that subtitle; and
the premises are not subject to any violation notice or order that:
has been issued under the Baltimore City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article; and
notwithstanding the passage of more than 90 days since its issuance, has not been abated before the license issuance or renewal.
