para.text: In this paragraph, "multiple–family dwelling" has the meaning stated in Article 13, § 5-1 of the Baltimore City Code.

Baltimore City may not issue or renew a multiple–family dwelling license unless the applicant demonstrates that a professional inspector {as defined in Public Safety Article § 12-203(a)(4)} has completed an inspection of the multiple–family dwelling to ensure that each balcony railing in the multiple–family dwelling meets the requirements of the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City.

Beginning in October 2015, and every 5 years thereafter, at the time that Baltimore City sends a renewal notice to a holder of a multiple–family dwelling license, Baltimore City shall notify the license holder of the inspection requirement under subparagraph (iii) of this paragraph.

section.heading: Prerequisites for new or renewal license – Inspection.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The inspection required by § 5-6 {"Prerequisites ... – In general"} of this subtitle must comply with either:
subsection (b) {"Third-party home inspections"} of this section;
subsection (c) {"Governmental agency inspections"} of this section; or
§ 5-10 {"Priority inspections"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subsection, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Home inspection.
para.text: "Home inspection" means a home inspector's written evaluation of a rental dwelling's compliance with the City's health and safety standards specified in the Housing Commissioner's rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Home inspector.
para.text: "Home inspector" means an individual:
who is licensed as a home inspector under Title 16, Subtitle 3A of the State Business Occupation and Professions Article; and
who, as required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle:
has registered with the Housing Commissioner as generally available to inspect and certify rental dwellings under this subsection;
has, as specified by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle, submitted to the Commissioner a conflict-of-interest statement; and

for each home inspection to be performed under this subsection, certifies that neither the home inspector nor any owner, partner, director, officer, employee, or agent of the home inspector or of the home inspector's business has any financial interest in:
the rental dwelling to be inspected;
the record owner or operator of that rental dwelling; or
any owner, partner, director, officer, employee, or agent of the rental dwelling's record owner or operator.

para.heading: Applicant to contract for timely inspection.

para.text: Before applying for a rental dwelling license or renewal license, the applicant must, at the applicant's expense, contract with a home inspector to perform a home inspection under this section.

Inspections may not be performed more than 90 days before a person submits an application for a rental dwelling license or an application for renewal of a rental dwelling license to the Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Number of units to be inspected.

para.text: For any rental dwelling that comprises 9 or fewer dwelling or rooming units, all dwelling and rooming units must be inspected under this subsection.

For any multiple-family dwelling or rooming house that comprises 10 or more dwelling or rooming units, the number of units that must be inspected are as determined in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.
After the home inspection, the home inspector must issue to the applicant:
a written report of every inspection conducted under this section; and
if the rental dwelling meets the City's health and safety standards specified in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle, a certificate of satisfactory compliance with those standards.
The reports and the certification must be:
in the form required by the Commissioner; and
signed by the home inspector, under oath and under the home inspector's seal.

para.heading: Scope of subsection.
para.text: This subsection applies to any rental dwelling unit that is required to undergo periodic inspections conducted by a governmental agency in accordance with Federal or State inspection standards.

para.heading: Required evidence of compliance with most recent inspection.
para.text: For a rental dwelling unit described in paragraph (1) of this subsection, the applicant for a license or renewal license may, in lieu of the requirements of subsection (b) {"Third-party home inspections"} of this section, submit evidence satisfactory to the Housing Commissioner that the unit has passed the most recent periodic inspection by the applicable governmental agency.

para.heading: Commissioner to audit inspections.
para.text: The Commissioner shall conduct an annual audit of inspections conducted under this section.

para.heading: Commissioner's inspection authority not affected.
para.text: This section does not in any way prevent or limit the authority of the Housing Commissioner to conduct routine, spot, quality-control, or other inspections of rental dwellings under the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article.

para.heading: Inspection reports – Distribution.
para.text: Inspection reports used to satisfy § 5-6 {"Prerequisites . . . – In general"} of this subtitle must be distributed by the record owner or, the managing operator, if other than the record owner, to each resident of the rental dwelling for which a person is applying for a new or renewed rental license at the time the application for a new or renewed license is submitted.

section.heading: License terms.
section.text: Each rental dwelling license and rental dwelling renewal license issued under this subtitle expires 2 years from the date of issuance.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A Department of Housing and Community Development inspector shall conduct priority inspections of at least 25 priority dwellings each inspection year.

para.heading: Definition - Inspection year.
para.text: In this subsection, the term "inspection year" means the calendar year.

para.heading: Identification of priority dwellings.
para.text: Based on data from the previous inspection year, the Department of Housing and Community Development shall identify all priority dwellings in the City by January 31st of each inspection year.

para.heading: Notification of priority dwelling status.
para.text: Upon identifying a priority dwelling, the Department of Housing and Community Development must notify the record owner and, if one exists, the managing operator, of the following:
the factors that are used to identify rental dwellings as priority dwellings; and;

that, because the dwelling is identified as a priority dwelling, a Department of Housing and Community Development inspector shall issue an environmental citation if a violation of a section of the City's Property Maintenance Code listed in Article 1, § 40-14(e) {"Provisions and penalties enumerated"} is identified.

para.heading: Number and frequency of inspections.
para.text: During each inspection year, at least 2 priority inspections must be conducted:
at least 4 months apart; and
between the months of February and November.

para.heading: Number of units to be inspected.
In general.
para.text: A Department of Housing and Community Development inspector shall attempt to inspect at least a certain percentage of the total dwelling and rooming units in the priority dwelling, as provided for in the table below.

para.heading: Documentation of inspections.
para.text: A Department of Housing and Community Development inspector shall record for each unit if the inspection was either 'attempted' or 'completed'.

para.heading: Notice and meeting requirements — Record owner and managing operator.
para.text: The Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee shall notify the record owner and the managing operator of a priority dwelling that:
the record owner and the managing operator shall attend a meeting at a time and place determined by the Commissioner or the Commissioner's designee to:
discuss unresolved violation notices, complaints, and property maintenance;
establish a schedule for the record owner and the managing operator to abate all unresolved violation notices;
establish a schedule for regular property maintenance to prevent future violations; and
any other matters deemed appropriate by the Commissioner or the Commissioner's designee; and
failure to attend the meeting described in paragraph (1) shall result in:
the denial of an application for a rental dwelling license;
the denial of an application for a renewal rental dwelling license; or
the revocation of a rental dwelling license.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The record owner or managing operator of a priority dwelling shall notify all tenants of the date and time of a priority inspection no fewer than 20 days prior to the date of the priority inspection.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The record owner and the managing operator shall deliver to all tenants directions to submit an anonymous request that the Department of Housing and Community Development inspector inspect the tenant's dwelling unit or rooming unit as part of the priority inspection.

para.heading: Form of instructions.
para.text: The Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee shall establish the form and content of the instructions delivered to tenants under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph.

section.heading: Posting license; license number.
section.text: The license issued under this subtitle must be prominently displayed:

para.text: for a multiple-family dwelling or rooming house, in the vestibule, lobby, or other public place on the premises; and
for a 1- or 2-family dwelling, in an area of each dwelling unit that is accessible to that unit's occupants and to housing inspectors.

para.heading: Lease agreements.
para.text: A license issued under this subtitle must be provided to:
any prospective tenant who requests an application; and
all existing or future tenants at the time a rental dwelling lease agreement or renewal lease agreement is:
offered;
executed; or
renewed.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any material advertising a rental dwelling for rent covered by this subtitle must include the rental license number for the advertised rental dwelling.

para.heading: Prohibitions.
para.text: Any material advertising a rental dwelling for rent that is covered by this subtitle may not include a rental license number that is, pursuant to this subtitle:
expired;
suspended; or
revoked.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Notwithstanding anything contained in this section to the contrary, the record owner and managing operator, if any, of a newly constructed or renovated dwelling unit or rooming unit that does not yet have a rental dwelling license number shall include the following text in any lease agreement, advertising material, or other publicly facing document:

"This is a newly constructed or renovated dwelling unit and does not currently have a rental license. As soon as available, a rental license will be provided to all individuals as required by Article 13, Subtitle 5 {"Licensing of Rental Dwellings"} of the Baltimore City Code.".

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The transfer of a rental license is prohibited under this subtitle.

para.heading: Application for new license.
para.text: A person shall apply for a new rental license according to the procedures established under § 5-5 {"Application for new or renewal license"} of this subtitle within 60 days of assuming:
record ownership of a rental dwelling; or
operation of a rental dwelling.

section.heading: Discontinuance of multiple-family or rooming-house operations.
section.text: Notwithstanding any discontinuance, in whole or in part, of a multiple-family dwelling's or a rooming house's operations, a license issued under this subtitle is still required unless the Housing Commissioner has issued a permit reflecting a change of use for the property.

section.heading: Denial, suspension, or revocation of license – In general.

para.heading: "Nuisance property" defined.
para.text: In this section, "nuisance property" means any property that is maintained or operated so as to cause or allow a nuisance of the sort described in any 1 or another of the following definitions:
State Code Real Property Article, § 14-120(a)(5) {defining "nuisance"};
City Code Article 19, § 43-1(l) {defining "public nuisance"};
City Code Article 19, § 43B-1(b) {defining "neighborhood nuisance"}; and
City Code Article 19, § 43B-1(o) {defining "unruly social event"}.

para.heading: Causes for denial, suspension, or revocation.
para.text: Subject to the hearing provisions of § 5-16 of this subtitle, the Housing Commissioner may deny, suspend, or revoke a rental dwelling license or renewal license for any of the following causes:
making any material false statement in an application for an initial or renewal license;
fraudulently or deceptively obtaining a rental dwelling license for oneself or for another;
fraudulently or deceptively using a rental dwelling license;
falsifying any inspection report or certificate;

refusal by a record owner or operator of a rental dwelling to allow the Commissioner to conduct a routine, spot, quality-control, proactive, or other inspection of the rental dwelling as authorized by this subtitle or the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article;

failing to abate within 120 days of issuance any violation notice, order, or citation for violating any provision of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, the City Health Article, or the Zoning Code of Baltimore City;
failing to abate any violation notice issued during a priority inspection within the time required;
failing to comply with any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle; or
if the Housing Commissioner finds, or if the Fire Chief, Health Commissioner, or Police Commissioner certify to the Housing Commissioner, that:

the record owner, operator, or lessee of a rental dwelling has failed to comply with any lawful notice, order, or citation to correct a violation that affects the health, safety, morals, or general welfare of the occupants of the property or of the general public; or
the record owner, operator, or lessee of a rental dwelling, or any agent of the owner or lessee:
has allowed the premises to be used as a nuisance property; or
knew or should have known that the premises were being used as a nuisance property and failed to prevent them from being so used.

section.heading: Denial, suspension, or revocation of license – Notice and hearing.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No license may be denied, suspended, or revoked unless the Housing Commissioner first gives the record owner, the managing operator, and the lessees of any dwelling or rooming unit to which the license applies:
not less than 10 days notice in writing of the Commissioner's intent to deny, suspend, or revoke the license; and
an opportunity to be heard as to why the license should not be denied, suspended, or revoked.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: The Commissioner may deny, suspend, or revoke a license without prior notice and opportunity to be heard if, in the opinion of the Commissioner or the Fire Chief, Health Commissioner, or Police Commissioner, the health, safety, or welfare of the occupants or of the general public are in imminent danger.

section.heading: Vacating premises.
section.text: The Commissioner may require a rental dwelling to be vacated within 24 hours if:

para.text: the property is being operated without a valid license; and
vacating the premises is necessary for the public health, safety, and welfare.

para.heading: "Reasonable accommodation" defined.
para.text: In this section, "reasonable accommodation" means affirmative steps that do not impose an undue financial hardship or a substantial burden.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: No bylaw, rule, or regulation governing a rental dwelling, nor any action or inaction of the governing body or management of a rental dwelling, may:
unreasonably impair any rights guaranteed by the Free-Exercise Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or by Article 36 of the Maryland Declaration of Rights; or
prohibit or deny any reasonable accommodation for religious practices.

para.heading: Preparation of Guide.
para.text: The record owner or managing operator of every rental dwelling, other than a hotel or motel, must prepare, in the form and containing the information required by the Commissioner, a Sanitation Guide for the premises that provides notice to all occupants of the requirements and procedures for the separation, disposition, collection, and proper storage pending collection of mixed refuse, recyclable materials, yard waste, bulk trash, and all other forms of garbage, rubbish, waste, and trash.

para.heading: Dissemination.
para.text: A copy of the Sanitation Guide must be:
provided to each dwelling unit on the premises; and
prominently posted within each common collection room, if any, on the premises.

section.heading: Public access to information.
section.text: The Housing Commissioner shall make freely available for review on and download from the website of the Department of Housing and Community Development:

para.text: the license number and license status of any rental dwelling subject to this subtitle;
the following records relating to that rental dwelling:
violation notices, orders, or citations issued by the Department of Housing and Community Development under this article or the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article; and
the rental dwelling's status as a priority dwelling for at least the past 5 years; and
notices of any denial, suspension, or revocation of the rental dwelling's license; and
the following information:
the address of the rental dwelling;
the name of the record owner of the rental dwelling;
the name of the managing operator of the rental dwelling;
phone numbers for both the record owner and the managing operator of the rental dwelling; and
phone numbers for both the record owner and the managing operator of the rental dwelling; and
email addresses for both the record owner and the managing operator of the rental dwelling.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A person aggrieved by a decision of the Housing Commissioner under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.
The filing of a petition for judicial review does not stay the decision of the Commissioner.
However, on motion and after hearing, the Court may grant a stay as provided in the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"} or a civil citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}.

para.heading: Priority dwelling – Citation.
para.text: For priority dwellings, a Department of Housing and Community Development inspector shall issue an environmental citation if a violation of a section of the City's Property Maintenance Code listed in Article 1, § 40-14(e) {"Provisions and penalties enumerated"} is identified.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of an environmental citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Separate Offenses.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle (including any offense listed in § 5-15 of this subtitle as potential cause for a denial, suspension, or revocation of a license) or any provision of a rule, regulation, or order adopted or issued under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commissioner, the City's Chief Data Officer, and any other City employee who maintains data pertaining to priority dwellings or priority inspections must collaborate to develop a system to track and analyze priority dwellings and priority inspections.

para.heading: Discretion of Commissioner.
para.text: The Department of Housing and Community Development may use existing resources to track and analyze priority dwellings at the discretion of the Commissioner.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Not later than May 1 of each year, the Department of Housing and Community Development must submit an annual report for the previous calendar year to the Mayor and the City Council detailing:
the number of priority dwellings;
the number of priority dwellings for which the Department of Housing and Community Development conducted 2 priority inspections;
the number of priority dwellings where at least 1 violation notice was issued during a priority inspection that was not abated within the allowable time;
the number of priority dwellings where at least 1citation was issued during a priority inspection;
the number of attempted priority inspections;
the number of rental licenses revoked under § 5-15(b)(6) of this subtitle;
the number of rental licenses revoked under § 5-15(b)(7) of this subtitle;
the total number of rental licenses revoked;
the number of completed priority inspections;
of the total number of priority inspections completed, the percentage of priority inspections that did not yield any violation notices or citations; and
any other information requested by the Mayor or by a Resolution of the City Council.

para.heading: Totals.
para.text: The annual report required under subsection (a) of this section must include a matrix identifying the following in aggregate for all licensed rental dwellings:
the total number of 3-1-1 complaints;
the total number of notices issued by the Department of Housing and Community Development;
the total number of notices abated within 90 days;
the number of notices for which the Department of Housing and Community Development pursued legal action; and
the total number of citations issued.

para.heading: Specific categories.
para.text: The annual report required under subsection (a) of this section must include a matrix identifying the data required under subsection (b)(1) of this section for all licensed rental dwellings in aggregate, for each of the following categories:
heating;
ventilation;
plumbing;
roof leaks;
rodents;
lead paint;
fire protections;
electrical systems;
water supply;
structural deficiencies;
insects;
elevators;
weatherproofing; and
appearance of mold

para.heading: Totals.
para.text: The annual report required under subsection (a) of this section must include a matrix identifying the following for all priority dwellings:
the total number of 3-1-1 complaints;
the total number of notices issued by the Department of Housing and Community Development;
the total number of notices abated within 90 days;
the number of notices for which the Department of Housing and Community Development pursued legal action; and
the total number of citations issued.

para.heading: Specific categories.
para.text: The annual report required under subsection (a) of this section must, for all priority dwellings, include a matrix identifying the data required under subsection (b)(1) of this section for each of the following categories:
heating;
ventilation;
plumbing;
roof leaks;
rodents;
lead paint;
fire protections;
electrical systems;
water supply;
structural deficiencies;
bed bugs; and
elevators.

section.heading: Statement of public policy and purpose.
section.text: It is the intent and purpose of this subtitle that before title to any single-family residential rental property is voluntarily transferred, the tenant of that property shall have the opportunity to purchase the property and that residential property owners shall not be unreasonably impeded in selling their properties nor required to accept unreasonable terms of sale.

para.text: In general.
In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings stated.
Commissioner.
"Commissioner" means the Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development, or the Commissioner's designee.
Landlord.
In general.
"Landlord" means any person who is the owner of a rental single-family dwelling unit.
Inclusion.

"Landlord" includes any person authorized to exercise any aspect of the management of the rental single-family dwelling unit, except those persons engaged solely in custodial and maintenance functions.
Owner.
"Owner" means any person recorded in the official records of the State or City as holding title to a rental single-family dwelling unit.
Rent.

"Rent" means the consideration, including any bonus, benefit, or gratuity, demanded or received per day, week, month, year, or other period of time, as the case may be, for the use or occupancy of housing accommodations or the transfer of a lease for those accommodations.

"Rent" includes any charge to a tenant under a rent-to-own agreement if the tenant's acceptance of the agreement is mandatory or if the tenant is not entitled to a refund of the charge if the tenant does not purchase the unit.
"Single-family dwelling unit" has the meaning stated in § 202.2.22.4 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

"Statement of interest" means a written and clear expression of interest to a landlord that the person writing the statement is interested in purchasing the landlord's rental single-family dwelling unit.
"Tenant" means any person who:
occupies a rental single-family dwelling unit as a residence with the consent of the landlord; and
has an obligation to pay rent or provide other consideration to the landlor for those accommodations.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: The following transfers of title are exempt from the requirements of this subtitle:

para.text: transfer of title to a spouse, child or children, parents, siblings, or in-laws of the landlord;
transfer of title by will or through inheritance under the State Estates and Trusts Article;
a gift to any religious, charitable, or benevolent, tax-exempt donee;
transfer of title in a mortgage or deed of trust;
transfer of title to a government agency;
transfer of, or for the sole purpose of creating, a reversionary (ground rent) interest, if the leasehold is retained by, or was not owned by, the transferor;
transfer of title in lieu of foreclosure of a mortgage or deed of trust;

any sale at public auction of a property individually, if the landlord has offered the property to the persons required under this subtitle, and those persons have failed to exercise the opportunity to purchase before the auction sale;
any transfer by a personal representative from a decedent's estate made in the course of the administration of the estate; [and]
a transfer of title by a bona fide gift to a relative of the transferor or relative of the transferor's spouse, subject to the following:

"relatives" means only those relatives set forth in § 267(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code and all lineal descendants and spouses of those relatives to the extent not already included in that section;
"ancestors" as defined in § 267(c)(4) are limited to the levels of parents and grandparents; and
"lineal descendants" include all biological children and stepchildren, and full effect shall be given to legal adoption[.] ; and
A tranfer of title by the housing authority of Baltimore City.
In general.
In this subtitle, the following rules of interpretation apply.
The time periods specified in this subtitle are minimum periods. A landlord may provide a tenant with reasonable extensions of time to purchase the rental single-family dwelling unit.
Presumption of knowledge.
Potential third-party purchasers are presumed to act with full knowledge of the rights and procedures established in this subtitle.
Unless otherwise expressly stated in this subtitle, delivery of items required by this subtitle shall be made either by first-class mail or hand-delivery to the required party.
To the extent possible, any defect or ambiguity in this subtitle shall be resolved in favor of tenants.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

container.heading: Opportunity to Purchase – Procedures and Requirements

section.heading: Opportunity to purchase - generally.
section.text: Before a landlord may settle on the sale of a rental single-family dwelling unit, the landlord shall give the tenant an opportunity to purchase the rental single-family dwelling unit at a price and under terms that constitute an offer of sale in accordance with the requirements of this subtitle.

para.text: Prior to offer the rental single-family dwelling unit for sale to another party, a landlord shall provide a written offer of sale to:
the tenant within the rental dwelling unit; and
the Commissioner, on behalf of the Mayor and City Council.
The offer of sale required by this section shall include:
the asking price and the material terms of sale; and
a statement that the landlord shall provide the tenant, within 7 calendar days of a request, the following:
a complete copy of any third-party contact to purchase the rental single-family dwelling unit, with the purchaser name redacted; and
copies of available licensing inspection reports of the rental single-family dwelling unit for the previous 2 years.

For each calendar day of delay by the landlord to provide the information required by subsection (b)(1)(ii) of this section, the time period for the tenant to express interest in purchasing the rental single-family dwelling unit or to negotiate a contract with the landlord for the purchase of the rental single-family dwelling unit, as the case may be, shall be extended by 1 day.
Additional Information
The landlord shall share the fact sheet regarding tenant rights under this section, which can be obtained from the Department of Housing and Community Development's office or website.
In this subsection, "material change" means:
a change in the purchaser under a third-party contact; or
a reduction in the sales price of 10% or more.

If there is a subsequent third-party contract after the initial offer of sale was transmitted that results in a material change or if the terms of a third-party contract to purchase the rental dwelling unit materially change between the time an offer of sale is made and the settlement, the landlord shall provide the tenant with a new offer of sale reflecting the new terms.

If the initial time period to indicate interest has expired, the tenant shall have all rights preserved under this subtitle except that the period to indicate interest in purchasing the rental single-family dwelling unit under the revised terms of sale may not exceed 7 calendar days from the date of receipt of the new offer of sale.
A landlord is not required to provide a new offer of sale if there is an increase in the sale price.
On receipt of offer of sale.
On receipt of the written offer of sale required by § 6-8 {"Offer of sale"} of this subtitle, a tenant shall have 14 calendar days to deliver a written statement of interest to the landlord.
Acceptance of offer of sale.
The tenant may accept the offer of sale by submitting a written contract within 14 calendar days from the date of the submission of the statement of interest.

The contract must include substantially the same terms and conditions set forth in the any third-party contract of sale, including any contract term that provides for a reasonable real estate commission.
Settlement; Financing.
In order for the tenant to secure financing, any contract of sale shall provide a reasonable period of no less than 30 days between the execution of the contract and settlement.
A landlord shall afford a tenant a reasonable and commensurate extension of time, if:
the tenant is obtaining financing through a government or other loan program designed for low- or moderate-income persons or first-time homebuyers; and
the government agency or other lender estimates in writing that a financing decision will be made within 60 calendar days after the date of the contract.
Expiration.

If 6 months elapses from the date the landlord has delivered the written offer of sale required by § 6-8 {"Offer of sale"} to a tenant and the landlord has not gone to settlement on the sale of the rental dwelling unit, the landlord shall send a new written offer of sale to the relevant parties before selling the rental dwelling unit.

section.heading: Assignment of rights.
section.text: The rights of a tenant under this subtitle may not be assigned and anyattempted assignment is void.

para.text: If a tenant proposes to use a federal, State, or local program to assist the purchase, for either mortgage insurance, a mortgage guarantee, or a direct mortgage, the required deposit shall not exceed the cash contribution required of the buyer by that program.
If no such program is involved in the tenant purchase, the deposit required for a sales contract shall be at least 1% of the purchase price.
No landlord may refuse to enter into a sales contract with a tenant solely because the tenant proposes to use a federal, State, or local program to assist in the financing of the purchase.
A sales contract shall contain a reasonable financing contingency clause which:
shall not require the tenant to obtain financing in less than 60 days from the date a contract is tendered by the landlord; and
shall excuse the tenant from performance of the sales contract if the tenant is unable to obtain adequate financing within said 60-day period.

section.heading: Waiver of rights.
section.text: Unless otherwise expressly stated, a landlord may not request, and the tenant may not grant, a waiver of any requirement under this subtitle unless the waiver is in exchange for consideration that the tenant, in their sole discretion, find acceptable.

section.heading: Affidavit on transfers to third parties.

para.text: In any transfer of real property subject to this subtitle to a party other than the tenant, the landlord shall file in the land records of Baltimore City, and with the Commissioner of the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development, an affidavit in the form set forth in subsection (c) of this section, certifying that the requirements of this subtitle have been met, as a part of the deed conveyance.

Where an affidavit has been filed as required by subsection (a) of this section, the rights and title of a third party transferee and the transferee's heirs, successors, or assigns shall be free of any restriction or claim arising in favor of the tenant under this subtitle.
The affidavit affirming compliance with the requirements of this subtitle described under subsection (a) of this section shall:
if the tenant has responded to the offer of sale required under this subtitle, include the following statement:

"(Name of tenant), being the tenant of the property known as (street address) in Baltimore City, following an offer of sale as required by § 6-7 of Article 13 of the Baltimore City Code, sent (date of mailing), has failed to enter into a contract to purchase said property in the manner and time provided by Subtitle 6 of Article 13 of the Baltimore City Code." (Add if applicable) "Notice pursuant to § 6-7 of Article 13 of the Baltimore City Code was subsequently sent to said tenant on (date of mailing), and tenant subsequently failed to contract to purchase said property in lieu of (name of third party) within the period of time provided by said § 6-8, that period being 7 days."; or
if the tenant has waived right of first refusal, include the following statement:

"(Name of tenant), being the tenant of the property known as (street address) in Baltimore City, following an offer of sale as required by § 6-7 of Article 13 of the Baltimore City Code, sent (date of mailing), has not entered into a contract for sale.

Where a rental single-family dwelling unit subject to this section is owned by a corporation, LLC, or other business organization, the affidavit required by subsection (a) of this section shall be made by a duly authorized officer of the organization or duly authorized representative of the ownership entity.
Landlord's duty to report.
A landlord shall report each rental single-family dwelling unit transfer subject to this subtitle to the Commissioner within 30 days of the transfer in the manner required by the Commissioner.
The duty to report under this subsection shall include transfers to a party other than the tenant.
Commissioner's annual report.
On or before June 30 of the each year, the Commissioner shall submit a report to the Mayor and City Council detailing:
disaggregated by zip code, the total number of transfers subject this subtitle, including:
transfers to a tenant; and
transfers to a party other than a tenant;
any recommendations for legislative or policy amendments to better ensure that City tenants are benefitting from this subtitle.
In general.
Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, shall be subject to a fine of up to $1,000 for each violation.
The criminal penalty described in this section is not intended to preclude any other civil or administrative remedy available at law.

container.heading: Tenants' Right to Counsel in Eviction Cases

annotation.text: The preceding subtitle was added by Ordinance 20-465. That Ordinance was enacted on December 2, 2020, but with a delayed effective date of April 1, 2021. Section 3 of Ord. 20-465 further provides for a phase-in of the program, as follows

para.text: Legal representation to all covered individuals in all covered proceedings, as set forth in this Ordinance, shall be phased-in during a period of time not to exceed 4 years, in a manner that the Commissioner, with the advice and consultation of the Commission determines appropriate based on all relevant factors, including those factors specified in subsection (b) of this Section.
Factors that the Commissioner and the Commission shall consider when phasing-in legal representation to covered individuals include:
the prioritization of individuals over the phase-in period;
the availability of funding from the City, State, and other sources, as the case may be;
the availability of trained and qualified attorneys to provide legal representation;
the scope of the need for legal representation; and
any other appropriate logistical consideration.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings specified.

para.heading: Commission.
para.text: "Commission" means the Baltimore City Affordable Housing Trust Fund Commission established by Article I, § 14 of the City Charter.

para.heading: Commissioner.
para.text: "Commissioner" means Commissioner of the Department of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Covered individual" means any individual who occupies a dwelling within the City of Baltimore under a claim of legal right other than the owner.

para.heading: Inclusion.
para.text: "Covered individual" includes any tenant in a building owned, operated, or managed by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Covered proceeding" means:
any judicial or administrative proceeding to evict or terminate the tenancy or housing subsidy of a covered individual;
any proceeding that is the functional equivalent of a proceeding described in item (i) of this paragraph; or
any first appeal of a proceeding described in item (i) or (ii) of this paragraph.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Covered proceeding" includes any judicial or administrative proceeding to remedy a violation of:
City Public Local Laws § 9-9 {"Rent Escrow Law: In general"};
City Public Local Laws § 9-9A {"Rent Escrow Law: Landlord's non- compliance with lease"};
City Public Local Laws § 9-10 {"Rent Escrow Law: Retaliatory actions"};
State Real Property Article § 8-208.1 {"Retaliatory actions due to reporting violations or complaints prohibited"}; or
State Real Property Article § 8-216 {"Restrictions relating to taking or threatening to take possession of dwelling unit"}.

para.heading: Designated organization.
para.text: "Designated organization" means any not-for-profit organization or association that is designated by the Commissioner under this subtitle and engaged pursuant to Article VI, § 11 of the City Charter regarding procurement that:
has the capacity to provide legal representation to covered individuals facing eviction; and
agrees to adhere to the standards of practice established in rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Designated community group.
para.text: "Designated community group" means a not-for-profit community organization or association designated by the Commissioner that has the capacity to conduct tenant outreach, engagement, education, and information regarding this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Legal representation" means ongoing legal representation provided by a designated organization to a covered individual and all legal advice, advocacy, and assistance associated with that representation.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Legal representation" includes the filing of a notice of appearance on behalf of the covered individual in a covered proceeding.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “includes” and “including”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-105.
See also § 6A-4 {“Additional Commission member”} of this subtitle.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner, with the advice and consultation of the Commission, shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle, including providing tenant education regarding their rights under this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Right to counsel in eviction-related proceedings.

para.text: Subject to provisions of this subtitle, including any rules and regulations, and with the advice and consultation of the Commission, the Commissioner shall ensure that all covered individuals are offered legal representation from a designated organization in a covered proceeding as soon as practicable after the initiation of that proceeding, but no later than at the time of the covered individual's first scheduled appearance in a covered proceeding if possible.
The Commissioner shall seek to prioritize the provision of legal representation based on median income with covered individuals having the lowest median income receiving the highest priority.

para.heading: Limitation.
para.text: Covered individuals shall receive legal representation unless circumstances specific to the individual or case, such as a conflict with the Maryland Attorneys' Rules of Professional Conduct, make legal representation infeasible to render.

para.heading: Engagement and education.
para.text: Subject to Article VI, § 11 of the City Charter regarding procurement, in addition to overseeing the administration of this subtitle, the Commissioner, with the advice and consultation of the Commission, may engage designated community groups to engage and educate tenants about their rights, through activities such as:
hosting know-your-rights trainings and other workshops for tenants;
distributing written information to tenants;
assisting tenants to form and maintain tenant associations;
referring tenants to designated community groups; and
engaging in any other activity designed to engage, educate, or inform tenants about their rights.

para.heading: Availability of funds.
para.text: Legal representation under this section is subject to the appropriation of funds in accordance with the City Charter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to those Commission members specified in Article I, § 14(d)(2) of the City Charter, the Mayor shall appoint an additional Commissioner in accordance with Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.

para.heading: "Extremely low-income household" defined.
para.text: In this subsection,"extremely-low income household" means a household whose aggregate gross income does not exceed 30% of the area median income, as adjusted for the size of the household.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Commission member appointed under this section shall be:
a tenant residing in Baltimore City; and
a member of an extremely low-income household.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No later than November 1 of each year, the Commissioner, with the advice and consultation of the Commission, shall submit a report to the Mayor and City Council, which shall include information from the prior fiscal year regarding:
the number of covered individuals served;
the extent of legal representation performed;
metrics on evaluating outcomes; and
the engagement and education of tenants.

para.heading: Posting.
para.text: The Commissioner shall prominently post the report required by this section on the City's website.

para.heading: Hearing.
para.text: No later than December 1 of each year, the City Council or an appropriate committee of the City Council shall conduct a hearing on the report required by this section.

This subtitle was added by Ordinance 21-040, effective October 30, 2021. Section 3 of the Ordinance further provides that the Ordinance “will remain effective through September 30, 2022, and, immediately after that date, with no further action by the Mayor and the City Council, this Ordinance will be abrogated and of no further effect”.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Executive Director of the Mayor's Office of Children and Family Success.

para.heading: Family.
para.text: "Family" means 1 or more individuals who reside together as a household.

para.heading: Mayor's Office.
para.text: "Mayor's Office" means the Mayor's Office of Children and Family Success.

para.heading: Program.
para.text: "Program" means the Baltimore City Emergency Security Deposit Grant Program.

para.heading: Security deposit.
para.text: "Security deposit" means an amount of money that a tenant pays to a landlord that the landlord must return to the tenant at the end of the lease minus any amount the landlord used for the tenant's:
non-payment of rent;
breach of the lease; or
damage to property.

para.heading: Security deposit grant; grant.
para.text: "Security deposit grant" or "grant":
means a one-time payment by the Program of up to $2,000 toward a security deposit; and
is not considered income to the tenant in determining the tenant's income eligibility, unless otherwise required by any state or federal law that governs the source of funds for this grant.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is an Emergency Security Deposit Grant Program in Baltimore City.

para.heading: Purpose.
para.text: The purpose of the Program is to provide families who are in need of permanent housing with security deposit grants for permanent housing.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Program shall be administered by the Mayor's Office.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to the requirements in this section and subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Mayor's Office shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this part {subtitle}.

para.heading: Hearing period.
para.text: In addition to the requirements set forth in the Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act - Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Mayor's Office must hold a public hearing prior to:
adopting any rules and regulations required by this section; or
amending or repealing any rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Application required.
para.text: Families seeking to participate in the Program shall submit an application to the Mayor's Office in the form the Mayor's Office requires.

para.heading: Eligibility.
para.text: A family is eligible to participate in the Program if the family:
resides in Baltimore City at the time of application; and
meets the income requirements for a grant.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to the provisions of this section, eligible families shall be admitted into the Program.

para.heading: Funding availability.
para.text: Admission into the Program is subject to the availability of funds and is not an entitlement.

para.heading: Manner of payment.
para.text: A security deposit grant made under this section {subtitle} shall be given directly to the landlord on behalf of the family.

para.heading: Audits.
para.text: The Mayor's Office shall conduct audits at least annually to ensure that families receiving security deposit grants are eligible for assistance.

section.heading: Grant priority; equity.
section.text: To ensure that grants are disbursed in an equitable manner, the Mayor's Office shall prioritize grant recipients based on:

para.text: median household income in the vicinity of a family's desired permanent housing, with areas with the lowest median income receiving highest priority; and
whether the family has received a security deposit grant from the Mayor's Office in a prior year.

section.heading: Denial of grant by the Mayor's Office.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Mayor's Office may deny a grant to a family if the Mayor's Office finds that the family:
failed to supply the information to the Mayor's Office required by this subtitle or the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
does not reside in Baltimore City at the time of application; or
does not meet the income requirements for a grant.

para.heading: Written notice of denial.
para.text: If the Mayor's Office denies a family's application for a grant, it must provide the family with a written notice of the denial, including the reasons for the denial, within 15 business days of the denial.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The family may appeal the Mayor's Office's denial to the Director of the Mayor's Office.

para.heading: Format of appeal.
para.text: In appealing the Mayor's Office's denial, the family must:
put the appeal in writing;
state the reasons why the Mayor's Office should have granted the grant; and
send the appeal to the Director within 15 business days of receipt of the Mayor's Office's written denial.

para.heading: Decision.
para.text: The Director must issue a written decision within business 15 days of receipt of the family's appeal.

section.heading: Compliance.
section.text: Tenants and landlords involved in the Program must comply with all State and local laws regarding security deposits.

section.heading: In general.
section.text: After August 1, 1981, any landlord who rents dwelling units by means of written leases shall comply with the following requirements.

section.heading: Copy of lease to tenant.
section.text: A copy of the lease, signed by tenant and landlord, shall be given to tenant at the time of signing of the lease.

para.text: Each residential lease must contain the following information:
the name, residence address, and residence telephone number or the name, business address, and business telephone number of the owner of the property, or

the name, residence address, and residence telephone number or the name, business address, and business telephone number of an agent of the owner who is authorized to receive court process on behalf of the owner in connection with the property.

Any owner who is not customarily present in an office in the metropolitan Baltimore area must include in the lease the information required above for an agent authorized to receive court process on behalf of the owner.

para.heading: Payment for water and wastewater services.

para.text: Any property owner or managing operator who requires that a tenant pay the costs of water or wastewater services, whether directly to the Department of Public Works or as reimbursement to the owner or managing operator, shall include that requirement in an express provision of a written lease.

The lease shall include a provision that the landlord makes the tenant a designee under Maryland's Public Information Act to request and to receive copies of any account records for the water or wastewater account at issue.
Whenever a landlord requires the tenant to reimburse the landlord for allocated costs of water or wastewater service, the lease required by this subsection shall also:
describe the calculation method used by the owner or owner's agent to allocate the cost of water and wastewater services to the tenant; and
specify the average monthly allocated costs of water and wastewater services for the leased dwelling unit or rooming unit in the 12 months preceding execution of the lease or renewal of the lease.

para.heading: "Government benefit" defined.
para.text: In this subsection, "government benefit" means:
temporary cash assistance or other assistance described in Title 5 of the State Human Services Article;
supplemental security income;
social security disability income;
unemployment insurance benefits;
Veteran's Administration benefits;
social security benefits; or
assistance from any other similar federal, state, or City government benefits program.

para.heading: Scope of subsection.
para.text: This subsection does not apply to leases for public housing administered by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A residential lease shall include a provision that the landlord may not apply late fees to the rent until the tenant is more than 10 days past due with the rent.

para.heading: Additional late fee provisions.
para.text: In addition, a residential lease that includes a provision permitting a landlord to apply a penalty for the late payment of rent must include a provision that prohibits a landlord from applying a penalty fee for late payment of rent until:
the tenant's payment of the rent is more than 10 days late; or

the tenant has received the tenant's regularly scheduled government benefit disbursement if the tenant has previously provided the landlord with written notice that shows the day of the month the government benefit is normally issued or mailed is later than the day on which the rent is due.
Within 10 days of a change in any information required by subsection (a) of this section to be contained in a lease, the property owner must notify the tenant of the change.
The notice must be sent to the tenant by first class mail.

Along with the copy of the lease required to be given to the tenant by § 7-2 of this subtitle, the tenant must be given a copy of a tenants rights brochure approved by the Housing Commissioner that discusses:
free or reduced price legal representation available to tenants;
pre-trial and day of trial mediation programs available to resolve landlord-tenant disputes; and
a tenant's right to know the amount of rent that is in arrears.
A tenant must also be given a copy of the brochure required by paragraph (1) of this subsection:
at the time that a lawsuit is commenced by the owner or landlord against the tenant;

if the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office is used to serve a summons and complaint by the landlord seeking eviction, including for summary ejectment, tenant holding over, or breach of lease, at the time that the summons and complaint are served on the tenant; and
at the time that the Housing Authority of Baltimore City sends a notice to terminate a tenant's subsidy or tenancy.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: The provisions of this subtitle do not apply to the following:

para.text: rental units in hotels, motels, inns, tourist homes and rooming and boarding houses which are rented primarily to transient guests for a period of less than 14 days, and
rental units in any hospital, convent, monastery, extended medical care facility, asylum, non-profit home for the aged, or dormitory owned and operated by an institution of higher education, and
individual rental units which a government unit, agency, or authority owns, operates, or manages, and
rental units within the premises occupied by the owner as his residence.

section.heading: Responsibility for compliance.
section.text: The owner of the property has primary responsibility for compliance with the provisions of this subtitle.

section.heading: Enforcement by tenant.
section.text: A tenant may seek relief from an appropriate court to restrain or enjoin any violation of the provisions of this subtitle.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any property owner or landlord who leases residential property under a written lease which does not conform to the provisions of this subtitle, or who fails to give a tenant a copy of the lease as provided in § 7-2 of this subtitle and the tenants rights brochure as provided in § 7-3(c) of this subtitle, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine of up to $100 for each violation.
